chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Managing suspected appendicitis
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of people with suspected appendicitis.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with suspected appendicitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a person presents with suspected acute appendicitis:
    • Arrange emergency hospital admission for specialist assessment and management. In particular, have a very low threshold for admitting:
      • People with suspected complications.
      • Pregnant women.
      • Elderly people.
      • Infants and young children.
  • If there is a low index of suspicion of acute appendicitis at initial presentation and hospital admission is not considered immediately necessary:
    • Consider arranging additional investigations in primary care to exclude alternative conditions, depending on clinical judgement.
    • Advise the person and/or parents of symptoms to be aware of, and when to seek urgent medical review.
    • The NHS leaflet Appendicitis and the patient.info leaflet Appendicitis may be helpful when giving safety-netting advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist assessment and management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Specialist management of suspected acute appendicitis may include:

  • Imaging investigations
    • Imaging studies in people with a clinical suspicion of acute appendicitis can reduce the negative appendectomy rate, which has been reported to be as high as 15%. Ultrasonography, abdominal computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are most commonly used [Gorter, 2016].
      • Selective imaging may be used when the diagnosis is uncertain given the risks, benefits, costs, and time delay to surgery associated with imaging [Howell, 2018].
      • Ultrasound should be the preferred imaging modality in children, pregnant, and breastfeeding women [Kabir, 2017; Synder, 2018].
      • MRI scans are mainly reserved for pregnant women when ultrasound is non-diagnostic [Baird, 2017].
  • Non-operative management
    • After negative imaging, a non-operative management strategy with intravenous fluids and antibiotics can be a safe and effective approach in selected patients with uncomplicated acute appendicitis [Bhangu, 2015; Synder, 2018; Di Saverio, 2020].
    • The reported rate of recurrence after non-surgical treatment for perforated acute appendicitis and phlegmon (pus-producing swelling) ranges from 12–24% [Di Saverio, 2020].
    • Appendix mass may be treated surgically or conservatively with intravenous antibiotics and possible percutaneous drainage [Stringer, 2017]. Perforated appendicitis may be managed non-operatively with antibiotics, with or without interval appendicectomy [Howell, 2018].
  • Operative management
    • Removal of the appendix is the gold standard treatment for uncomplicated appendicitis [Gorter, 2016].
    • In people with progressive or persistent pain, explorative laparoscopy is recommended to establish/exclude the diagnosis of acute appendicitis or alternative diagnoses [Di Saverio, 2020].
      • Laparoscopic appendicectomy offers significant advantages over open appendicectomy in terms of less pain, lower incidence of surgical site infection, decreased length of hospital stay, earlier return to work, overall costs, and better quality of life scores [Synder, 2018; Di Saverio, 2020].
      • Possible postoperative complications include small bowel obstruction, superficial wound infection, intra-abdominal abscess, stump leakage, and stump appendicitis [Gorter, 2016; Di Saverio, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management are largely based on the European Association of Endoscopic Surgery (EAES) guideline Diagnosis and management of acute appendicitis. EAES consensus development conference 2015 [Gorter, 2016], the World Society of Emergency Surgery (WSES) consensus guidelines Diagnosis and treatment of acute appendicitis: 2020 update of the WSES Jerusalem guidelines [Di Saverio, 2020], consensus guidelines developed by the WSES together with various Italian Societies The SIFIPAC/WSES/SICG/SIMEU guidelines for diagnosis and treatment of acute appendicitis in the elderly (2019 edition) [Fugazzola, 2020], a systematic review on diagnostic accuracy [Kabir, 2017], and expert opinion in review articles on acute appendicitis [Bhangu, 2015; Baird, 2017; Rentea, 2017; Stringer, 2017; Howell, 2018; Synder, 2018] and on acute abdominal pain in children [Reust, 2016].

Arranging emergency hospital admission
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment of appendicitis are important to reduce the risk of complications, which increases with duration of symptoms [Howell, 2018]. A delay in diagnosis and appendicectomy can increase the risk of perforated appendicitis, which is associated with higher incidence of short- and long-term morbidity [Gorter, 2016].
    • The recommendation to admit people with suspected complications is owing to the fact appendiceal perforation is associated with increased morbidity and mortality compared with non-perforating acute appendicitis, with a mortality rate of about 5% [Di Saverio, 2020]. In addition, perforation may lead to an increased length of hospital stay, extended antibiotic administration, and more severe postoperative complications [Synder, 2018].
    • The recommendation to have a low threshold to admit pregnant women is based on the fact appendicitis may increase the risk of fetal loss and pre-term delivery [Baird, 2017]. In addition, appendicitis may present atypically in these women, who may need additional tests or imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis [Bhangu, 2015; Synder, 2018; Di Saverio, 2020].
    • The recommendation to have a low threshold to admit older people is based on the possible atypical presentation, and increased risk of complications such as perforation in this age group [Bhangu, 2015; Di Saverio, 2020; Fugazzola, 2020].
    • The recommendation to have a low threshold to admit children is based on the challenges of diagnosis and possible atypical presentation in this age group [Rentea, 2017; Stringer, 2017; Howell, 2018; Di Saverio, 2020].
Management if low index of suspicion at initial presentation
  • This recommendation is largely pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • The recommendation to consider arranging additional investigations in primary care is based on the EAES guideline [Gorter, 2016], the WSES guidelines [Di Saverio, 2020], a systematic review on diagnostic accuracy [Kabir, 2017], and expert opinion in review articles [Bhangu, 2015; Reust, 2016; Baird, 2017; Stringer, 2017; Synder, 2018].
